data.question: Can you provide practice problems on multiplying two matrices?

docs.title: 674dcdb4b00b977d048c931b
docs.text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

docs.title: 674dcde1b00b977d048c9352
docs.text: Two outlets of a coffee chain sell three different types of coffee: espresso, flat white and mocha. The table shows the number of cups of each type of coffee sold on a particular day. Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).

By using matrix multiplication, calculate the total amount of money the dance school earns for this 10-week block of sessions.

Correct your answer to the nearest cent.

data.output: A stadium sells tickets for three types of seats: VIP, Regular, and Economy. The ticket prices are $100 for VIP, $50 for Regular, and $25 for Economy. On a particular Friday, the numbers of VIP, Regular, and Economy seats sold were 180, 300, and 120, respectively. On Saturday, the stadium sold 200 VIP, 320 Regular, and 150 Economy seats. Represent the number of seats sold on Friday and Saturday as a matrix $S$, and the prices as a matrix $P$. Then, calculate the total revenue for each day by finding the matrix $R = SP$. Explain what the elements of matrix $R$ represent.

In a theater, tickets are sold at different prices for adults, students, and children. The ticket prices are $60 for an adult, $45 for a student, and $25 for a child. On a Friday, there were 120 adults, 300 students, and 50 children. On the following Saturday, there were 150 adults, 280 students, and 60 children. Represent the information of visitors using the matrix \( A = \begin{pmatrix} 120 & 300 & 50 \\ 150 & 280 & 60 \end{pmatrix} \).

(i) Write a 3x1 matrix, \( B \), to represent the price of the theater tickets.

(ii) Find the matrix \( C = AB \).

(iii) Explain what each of the elements in matrix \( C \) represents.

(iv) Calculate the total amount collected from ticket sales over these two days.

At a community theater, tickets for plays are priced at $40 for regular seats, $60 for premium seats, and $100 for VIP seats. On a given weekend, the following number of tickets were sold: 140 regular, 70 premium, and 40 VIP on Saturday, and 120 regular, 60 premium, and 50 VIP on Sunday. Represent the sales data using matrices, and calculate the total revenue for each day.

(i) Write a 1x3 matrix for the ticket prices.

(ii) Represent the number of tickets sold each day with a 2x3 matrix.

(iii) Multiply the matrices to find the total sales for each day.

(iv) Explain what the result of your multiplication represents.

A bookstore sells three types of books: fiction, non-fiction, and children's books. On a particular weekend, Store A sold 120 fiction, 75 non-fiction, and 45 children's books. Store B sold 185 fiction, 95 non-fiction, and 70 children's books. The matrix representing the number of books sold is given by:

$$ B = \begin{pmatrix} 120 & 75 & 45 \\ 185 & 95 & 70 \end{pmatrix}. $$

The prices of the books are $25, $30, and $20 for fiction, non-fiction, and children's books respectively. Create a 3x1 price matrix, calculate the total revenue for each store by multiplying the matrices, and interpret the results. Finally, find the overall total revenue for the weekend sales.

A theme park sells tickets for rides as follows: $60 for an individual, $90 for a couple, and $180 for a family. On a certain weekend day, there were 120 individuals, 95 couples, and 55 families who visited. Represent the numbers of visitors by the matrix \( V = \begin{pmatrix} 120 & 95 & 55 \end{pmatrix}^T \).

(i) Write a \(3 \times 1\) matrix, \(P\), to represent the ticket prices.

(ii) Calculate the matrix \( T = VP \).

(iii) Explain what the elements of the resulting matrix \(T\) represent.

(iv) Find the total revenue collected from ticket sales on that day.
